Where do we go when we die? 

For these seven people, the answer is space. They have chosen to send their ashes, or a sample of their DNA, into orbit, to the moon or simply hurtling into space. They settled on their final wishes for different reasons: spiritual, pragmatic, romantic. Many consider it the culmination of a lifelong fascination with space exploration, the impulse to look up with wonder. Lemuel Patterson, 71 (Photo 1), has always been enraptured by space and wants to be buried up there.  For others, a space burial signals acceptance of the idea that, in the end, there may be only a void awaiting us. 

To read their stories, tap the link in our bio. Photos by @dina_litovsky

The new crop of e-cigarettes represents an about-face from the more subdued look of its predecessors. That has experts concerned.

The understated look associated with Juul has been supplanted by the rounded, vivid designs of Elf Bars and other brands, whose color schemes often correspond with their flavors. Some public health experts are concerned that these devices‚Äô playful appearance ‚Äî which is neatly in line with the maximalist aesthetic preferences of many members of Gen Z ‚Äî may offer appealing new cover for nicotine products.

Each Elf Bar contains as much nicotine as 590 cigarettes, according to one estimate. Doctors say that nicotine is especially addictive for young people, and research suggests that teenage vapers risk both immediate and long-term lung damage.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how these products are geared to catch the eyes of young people. Photo illustration and photos by @ok__mccausland

Vietnam is having a cable car bonanza. The country is home to four of the longest cable cars in the world, and some 26 cable car lines have been built in a dozen locations across Vietnam over the past two decades.

Vietnam‚Äôs abundance of mountains, jungles and islands makes cable cars a natural fit since they can be built faster, cheaper and with less environmental damage than roads. But the cable cars are typically parts of mass-tourism complexes, and some travelers, citizens and environmental activists see them as scars on the landscape and a symptom of rampant overdevelopment by powerful conglomerates. Environmentalists are also anxious over the vision for Cat Ba Island from the Sun Group, one of the communist country‚Äôs biggest real estate and tourism developers. The on-again, off-again plans include a network of cable cars, a resort, a golf course and a cruise ship port, all in an area designated by UNESCO as a Biosphere Reserve.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about this booming mode of transportation in Vietnam. Photos by @askmott

‚ÄòIs It Good Enough to Fool My Gallerist?‚Äô

David Salle, one of America‚Äôs most thoughtful painters, hoped an AI program could nourish creativity. For nearly a year, the painter has tried to defy conventional thinking about generative artificial intelligence by testing an AI program‚Äôs capacity to become a sophisticated creator of art.

Salle held weekly meetings with two technologists, Danika Laszuk and Grant Davis, who tailored a text-to-image model to the painter‚Äôs requirements, relying on descriptive prompts that generated images in the artist‚Äôs style. The New York Times observed three of their work sessions, tracking the algorithm‚Äôs progress over several months as it adopted more of Salle‚Äôs techniques and abandoned the bland photorealism that often limits other generative programs.

Tap the link in our bio for more from Zachary Small, a culture reporter for The New York Times, who explained Salle‚Äôs approach to AI. Video by @zacharyhsmall, @claire_sandwich and @rurukuooo

Nearly a million miles away, the James Webb telescope just took a picture. Since transmitting its first data, it has made stunning discoveries, including a plume of water spanning 6,000 miles and a galaxy that formed more than 13 billion years ago.

The telescope is an engineering marvel: Its massive mirror makes it possible to collect light from the faintest objects. It has multiple ways of blocking and dissecting that light, giving us detailed portraits of distant galaxies and close neighbors alike.

Barry Manilow is finally getting his wish: a Broadway show.

The musical, ‚ÄúHarmony,‚Äù tells the story of the Comedian Harmonists, a singing group torn apart by the rise of Nazism and World War II. It is a decades-in-the-making labor of love for Manilow and his longtime collaborator Bruce Sussman, who first conceived of the show in the early 1990s. 

‚ÄúHarmony‚Äù debuted in San Diego in 1997 to mixed reviews, and failed to transfer. A planned Broadway run evaporated when financial backing disintegrated. Many iterations of the musical followed, but Broadway deals fell apart. ‚ÄúIt was so heartbreaking every time it didn‚Äôt make it,‚Äù Manilow, the singer, said in an interview. The Signs Were All There. Why Did No One Stop the Maine Shooter?

The shooter who killed 18 people with an assault-style rifle in Lewiston, Maine, displayed a textbook set of warning signs: He was hearing voices. He told people that he was planning violence. After a long career as America‚Äôs most famous and least likely sex counselor, Dr. Ruth Westheimer has turned her attention to the epidemic of loneliness in the U.S. Last year, she set out to become the Loneliness Ambassador for New York State.

Loneliness has been on the rise since before the pandemic but escalated because of lockdowns and social distancing requirements. In May, the U.S. surgeon general issued an advisory that isolation can be just as deadly as smoking up to 15 cigarettes a day and can pose a greater risk to longevity than being sedentary or obese.

At times, Washington, D.C. can feel like a tale of two cities: politicians and temporary dwellers versus multigenerational residents fighting to hold on to their piece of the district.
 
Once known as ‚ÄúChocolate City‚Äù because of its predominantly African American population, Washington has seen its demographics shift dramatically in recent decades, bringing both positive and negative effects of gentrification. The second phase of the Wharf district, a $3.6 billion development, has contributed a new Pendry luxury hotel and splashy dining destinations, all set against the backdrop of skyrocketing living costs (only recently cooling), increased crime and ongoing questions of cultural identity. But even in this time of transition, Washington is still a hub of art, history and social justice leadership, and is home to many of the best free museums and monuments in the world.

New York City is legally obligated to provide a bed for every homeless person who asks for one, under a decades-old court settlement. But 18 months into a migrant crisis that shows no signs of abating, it has walked away from its obligation, at least for some people.

The city, which is currently providing emergency shelter to more than 65,000 migrants, is no longer guaranteeing beds for single adults who have hit the city‚Äôs 30-day or 60-day limit on stays at any one migrant shelter.

With so much hinging on refilling the ranks, efforts are underway to draw more Ukrainian women into the army. Volunteer groups offering all-female training are supporting the effort.

About 43,000 women now serve in the Ukrainian military, according to the ministry of defense, an increase of about 40% since 2021, the year before Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion. Ukrainian women are in combat in southeastern Ukraine now. After the invasion, the military abolished restrictions that kept women from roles such as machine gunner, tank commander and sniper, and lifted rules prohibiting women from driving trucks. It raised the age limit for female recruits, previously 40, to 60, the same as for men.

‚ÄúThe gender of a warrior makes no difference,‚Äù said Darya Trebukh, the founder of the nongovernmental group, Ukrainian Valkiriya, that is leading the training sessions.

Third GOP Debate: Haley and DeSantis Take Leading Roles

The third Republican presidential debate on Wednesday devolved at times into brutal personal attacks as the five candidates onstage tried to discuss high-minded issues from the fate of Social Security to the role of America abroad between cutting asides and provocative insults.

The most heated exchange came over the unlikely issue of TikTok. After Vivek Ramaswamy bragged about using the Chinese-owned social media network to broadcast his message, he turned to his adversary, Nikki Haley, and mocked her daughter for using the app.

But the debate did address weighty issues: whether a soaring budget deficit required a higher retirement age for access to Social Security and Medicare, how the U.S. should back Israel against Hamas and Ukraine against Russia, and how a president could immediately address the strain of inflation in everyday life.

Tap the link in our bio to read more from Wednesday‚Äôs GOP debate.

One of the longest labor crises in Hollywood history is finally coming to an end.

SAG-AFTRA, the union representing tens of thousands of actors, reached a tentative deal for a new contract with entertainment companies on Wednesday, clearing the way for the $134 billion American movie and television business to swing back into motion.

Hollywood‚Äôs assembly lines have been at a near-standstill since May because of a pair of strikes by writers and actors, resulting in financial pain for studios and for many of the two million Americans ‚Äî makeup artists, set builders, location scouts, chauffeurs, casting directors ‚Äî who work in jobs directly or indirectly related to making TV shows and films.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about how the actors union and entertainment companies agreed to a deal.

Shell email accounts, phantom truckers, supply-chain fraud and one seriously bewildered cargo freight broker. This is the long, strange story of one stolen load of valuable cargo in the form of 55,000 rare Kit Kats.

Sought-after Kit Kat flavors like melon, matcha latte and daifuku mochi are a booming business. In Japan, enthusiasts clamor for the rarer flavors, with some sold for just a few weeks or only in a specific region. In the United States, obsessives fawn over the collectibles, comparing reviews on Japanese snack blogs and shelling out for limited editions.

Danny Taing, the founder of a New York company that sells Japanese snacks in subscription boxes, had bought $110,000 worth of the sweets, expecting to make about $250,000 in total revenue. The shipment arrived Stateside from Japan, but somewhere along its cross-country journey, it went missing. What happened?

Yusef Salaam, who was one of five Black and Latino teenagers convicted in the 1989 rape of a jogger in Central Park and exonerated decades later, was elected on Tuesday night to represent Harlem in the New York City Council.

Cherelle Parker, a longtime state and local elected official who promised Philadelphia residents that she would aggressively tackle the city‚Äôs crime woes, was elected mayor Tuesday, according to The Associated Press, making her the first woman voted into the city‚Äôs highest office.

With registered Democrats vastly outnumbering Republicans in the city ‚Äî the nation‚Äôs sixth most populous, with 1.6 million residents ‚Äî Parker‚Äôs primary win gave her a significant advantage over the Republican nominee, David Oh, a former colleague of hers on the City Council.

On Wednesday, the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Zoo in Washington, D.C., will say goodbye to a family of giant pandas. 

Mei Xiang and Tian Tian, and their 3-year-old cub, Xiao Qi Ji, are scheduled to be loaded into crates and driven in trucks to a FedEx Boeing 777 called the Panda Express. They will then be flown 19 hours from Dulles International Airport to China, where they will join about 150 other pandas in a lush nature preserve in the misty mountains of Sichuan Province.

Giant pandas have been a fixture in Washington since 1972, when China sent the U.S. two pandas after Patricia Nixon, the first lady, mentioned her fondness for pandas to China‚Äôs premier during the landmark visit she and Richard Nixon made to Beijing. But U.S.-China tensions have been rising for years, and now there is speculation that China is asking for the return of the pandas because of the diplomatic deep freeze. Now, only one zoo in the U.S. will have giant pandas, but they are expected to return to China next year.

Ohio voters approved a ballot measure on Tuesday to enshrine a right to abortion in the State Constitution, according to The Associated Press. This continues a series of wins for abortion-rights groups that have appealed directly to the public as they try to recover from the U.S. Supreme Court‚Äôs overturning of Roe v. Wade.

Issue 1, as the ballot measure is known, had become a closely followed part of Tuesday‚Äôs off-year elections. Both parties are looking to gauge whether voter anger over the loss of the federal right to abortion might help Democrats in next year‚Äôs presidential and congressional races. National groups on both sides of the debate poured money into Ohio in recent weeks.

The ‚Äúyes‚Äù vote in Ohio, a conservative-leaning state, is likely to help lift the hopes of abortion-rights groups that are pushing similar measures next year in red and purple states, such as Arizona, South Dakota, Missouri and Florida. Tap the link in our bio to read more about the Ohio vote.

Maybe it‚Äôs her grandkids, maybe it‚Äôs being 81, but Barbra Streisand is open to new stuff. Take sharing. Well, take sharing about herself.

‚ÄúMy Name Is Barbra,‚Äù her first memoir, is upon us. It‚Äôs 970 pages and billows with doubt, anger, ardor, hurt, pride, persuasion, glory and Yiddish. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know that any artist has done more sharing,‚Äù writes @wsslyy, a critic at large for The New York Times.

Streisand talked to The Times about her new memoir, exploring the movies and men of her life, and her determination to control her own art. ‚ÄúIf you want to read about me in 20 years or 50 years, whatever it is ‚Äî if there‚Äôs still a world ‚Äî these are my words,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúThese are my thoughts.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read the full interview with @barbrastreisand, in which she speaks candidly about what‚Äôs in her new book. Photo by @ryanpfluger

Kimberly Mata-Rubio, the mother of one of the 19 children killed in the mass shooting last year in Uvalde, Texas, is now running for mayor. 

Mata-Rubio, a former news reporter, would be the first woman and only the third Latino to lead the Hispanic majority city, one that has been bitterly divided in the aftermath of one of the nation‚Äôs deadliest mass shootings. 

As president of Lives Robbed, an organization made up of mothers and grandmothers of the Uvalde victims, Mata-Rubio has organized rallies, flown to Washington and sat through legislative hearings in Austin, the Texas capital. Still it did not feel like she was doing enough.

A proposed marine sanctuary in California is facing challenges after a last-minute boundary change to accommodate a wind farm.

The Chumash Heritage National Marine Sanctuary, a 7,573-square-mile area that would include 156 miles of coastline along central California, would limit offshore oil drilling, acoustic underwater testing and other activities. The sanctuary would also provide funding for research and protection to numerous sites, both on and offshore, that are sacred to the Northern Chumash, a tribe that has inhabited California‚Äôs coastline for thousands of years.

But the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration has thrown a wrench into those plans. In an effort to allow for the development of an offshore wind energy project, NOAA has suggested shifting the sanctuary‚Äôs borders to remove a section of the coastline that includes Morro Bay and Morro Rock ‚Äî or Lisamu‚Äô, a site sacred to the Chumash that the tribe has been planning to make the hub of the sanctuary.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the challenges facing the first tribal-led effort in the U.S., which is also guided by Native history, culture and knowledge. Photos by @photographnic

There are unwritten rules when riding the New York City subway.

No eye contact. No blocking doors. No hogging seats.

Three years after the coronavirus nearly wiped out ridership in the nation‚Äôs largest transportation network, millions of travelers are reacquainting themselves with transit‚Äôs informal customs. The pandemic had suspended these protocols as many passengers stayed home. But now, in a sign that normalcy might be returning, old subway tensions are creeping back as more riders pack into the system.

What are New Yorkers‚Äô top rules for riding the subway? Tap the link in our bio to find out. Photos by @cherkis

Trapped in a territory under siege, Palestinians are documenting and sharing, on Instagram, their harrowing experiences of life under Israeli airstrikes and a ground invasion. One month into the war, @motaz_azaiza and @hindkhoudary have amassed huge followings for their raw and intimate videos. Their posts have led some Israeli media outlets to accuse them of being Hamas propagandists. And yet, Azaiza and Khoudary are living through the war they are covering: surviving intense bombardments, burying their colleagues, watching their homes crumble, and pulling their own families from the rubble.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full story. Video by @nik_olov_ and @yousuralhlou

For more than a century, Lessie Benningfield Randle, one of the last known survivors of the 1921 Tulsa race massacre, has lived with the searing details of that spring. For decades, she has recalled the fire that ravaged her neighborhood, Greenwood, and the frantic trip with her grandmother to the safety of a fairground.

Randle‚Äôs 109th birthday is Friday. She was 6 years old when a white mob attacked Greenwood with indiscriminate violence that wrought death and destruction and erased much of the promise of economic stability for future generations. She and the only other known survivor, Viola Fletcher, 109, are united in a historic legal battle to force the City of Tulsa and others to answer for the massacre.

‚ÄúI would like to see justice. It‚Äôs past time. I would like to see this all cleared up and we go down the right road,‚Äù Randle said in an interview with The New York Times. ‚ÄúBut I do not know if I will ever see that.‚Äù

On Monday, a team of lawyers representing Randle, Fletcher and the estate of Fletcher‚Äôs younger brother, took what they consider to be the last legal step in their long quest for justice. Tap the link in our bio to read Randle‚Äôs full story and to learn about the latest in her legal battle. Photo by @michaelnoblejr

LeVar Burton, who hosted the children‚Äôs TV show ‚ÄúReading Rainbow,‚Äù is engaging young audiences again with ‚ÄúSound Detectives,‚Äù a comic mystery podcast that teaches the art of listening.

Burton, who played Geordi La Forge on ‚ÄúStar Trek: The Next Generation‚Äù and Kunta Kinte in ‚ÄúRoots,‚Äù is best remembered by many parents for ‚ÄúReading Rainbow.‚Äù In the podcast, Burton and his team try to solve a mystery about an errant sound, which they identify, and then interview real-life experts who discuss it.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about @levar.burton‚Äôs first podcast for children which, he stressed, he did not see as a long-awaited return to young people‚Äôs entertainment. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt feel like I‚Äôve ever left it,‚Äù he said. Photo by @arielfish

Hundreds of protestors, led by the activist group Jewish Voice for Peace, rallied in front of the Statue of Liberty on Monday to call for a cease-fire in Gaza.

It was the latest in a series of protests, vigils and other events that Americans on opposing sides of the conflict between Israel and Hamas have organized almost daily in cities across the country since the beginning of the war. In a rally outside Israel‚Äôs Parliament, hundreds demand more action on hostages.

Hundreds of people gathered around the Knesset, Israel‚Äôs Parliament, in Jerusalem on Monday to demand again that the Israeli government do more to bring hundreds of hostages home ‚Äî repeating one word, over and over: ‚ÄúNow, now, now.‚Äù

It was the latest rally since 242 were kidnapped after Hamas stormed across the border in an attack that killed at least 1,400 people. The hostages include civilians and soldiers from more than 40 countries.

When @rebeccayarros pitched her publisher a sexy fantasy about telepathic dragons and their riders, she thought it might be a tough sell. However, ‚ÄúFourth Wing‚Äù ‚Äî an intricately plotted 500-plus-page narrative that takes place at an elite war college as two dragon riders feud, then fall in love ‚Äî became a huge best seller. And on Tuesday, after much anticipation, the novel‚Äôs follow-up, ‚ÄúIron Flame,‚Äù the second installment of a planned five-book series, is scheduled to publish.

The runaway success of ‚ÄúFourth Wing‚Äù stems in part from Yarros‚Äôs experience with chronic illness and her life in a military family, which she drew on while crafting the novel.
‚ÄúWriting Violet is super cathartic, because she struggles to accept the accommodations that are given to her, and I have that same struggle,‚Äù Yarros said in an interview with The New York Times.

Tap the link in our bio to read the full profile of Yarros ‚Äî and to learn about ‚ÄúFourth Wing‚Äù and ‚ÄúIron Flame.‚Äù Photo by @joanna_kulesza

The Golden Gate Bridge, a rare blend of form and function, stands as an engineering marvel, an emblem of Depression-era American muscle. But it has a darker legacy, too: About 2,000 people are known to have died by jumping off the bridge. The true tally is certainly higher, since not all jumps are witnessed and not all bodies are found. 

Such tragedies, officials hope, are mostly in the past. After decades of pleas to raise the rail, workers are nearly finished installing 3.5 miles of stainless-steel nets ‚Äî a ‚Äúsuicide deterrent system,‚Äù officials call it ‚Äî strung on both sides of the bridge, end to end. The nets, which are nearly invisible from a distance, were chosen to appease those worried about altering the bridge‚Äôs iconic look or obstructing its famous views. But the nets can be seen by anyone standing at the rail, hanging about 20 feet down and stretching about 20 feet out. They are taut, marine-grade stainless steel nets meant to withstand the Golden Gate‚Äôs combination of rain, wind, salt and fog.

Tap the link in our bio to learn more about the long fight to make the bridge safer. Photos by @jimwilson125 

If you are having thoughts of suicide, call or text 988 to reach the 988 Suicide and Crisis Lifeline or go to SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources for a list of additional resources.

For Donald Trump, a new set of New York Times/Siena College polls captures a stunning, seemingly contradictory picture.

His 91 felony charges in four different jurisdictions have not significantly hurt him among voters in battleground states. Yet he remains weaker than at least one of his Republican rivals, and if he‚Äôs convicted and sentenced in any of his cases, some voters appear ready to turn on him ‚Äî to the point where he could lose the 2024 election.

Trump leads President Biden in five key battleground states ‚Äî Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Nevada and Pennsylvania, according to the Times/Siena polls.

Donald Trump‚Äôs trial will continue Monday in a New York courtroom with him on the witness stand, part of a proceeding that threatens the business empire that underpins his public persona and that fostered his run for the White House.

New York‚Äôs attorney general, Letitia James, called Trump to the witness stand at his own civil fraud trial in Manhattan, where, under oath and under fire, the former president will try to convince a single skeptical judge ‚Äî not a jury ‚Äî that he played no role in the inflation of his net worth to defraud banks and insurers.

Privately, Trump has told advisers that he is not concerned about his time on the stand. He held preparation sessions when he was in New York attending the trial, according to people briefed on the matter. Trump is deeply, personally enraged by this trial ‚Äî and the fact that his children have had to testify, according to several people who have spoken with him ‚Äî and he may not be able to restrain himself on the stand.

We‚Äôre covering the fraud trial live. Tap the link in our bio for the latest updates. Photo by Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times

Doctors and nurses in Gaza‚Äôs teetering hospitals, which are nearing collapse without electricity and basic supplies, say they must now decide which patients get ventilators, who gets resuscitated, or who gets any medical treatment at all. They make snap decisions amid the screams of small children undergoing amputations or brain surgeries without anesthesia or clean water to wash their wounds.

Some veterans of wartime medicine in the Gaza Strip say conditions inside the overcrowded and impoverished territory are the worst they have ever seen, as entire apartment blocks, schools and hospitals crumble under an Israeli bombardment that has left a devastating civilian toll.

New Yorkers turned out in droves to cheer on thousands of runners in the New York City Marathon. Some 50,000 athletes are competing in the New York City Marathon under clear skies and unseasonably warm temperatures, and many more people have lined the race course across all five boroughs to cheer them on.

Marathon Day is something of an unofficial holiday for New York City, as people come out with costumes, cowbells, live music and pun-filled signs to support the runners.

Last year, 47,839 marathoners from 131 countries finished the race. Their average time across the finish line in Central Park was 4 hours 50 minutes 26 seconds.

You can read our earlier coverage of the marathon at the link in our bio. Photos by @rosemmorton, @karstenmoran, Earl Wilson/The New York Times, @hiroko.masuike, @wattsanna_, @adriennegrunwald and @maansi.photo

Tamirat Tola of Ethiopia set a course record in his first New York City Marathon, while Hellen Obiri of Kenya broke away from a pack of elite women at the end of the race for a dramatic victory. Obiri finished in an unofficial time of 2:27:23. Tola finished in an unofficial time of 2:04:59.

Switzerland dominated the wheelchair races. Catherine Debrunner easily won her first New York marathon in a time of 1:39:32, a course record. And Marcel Hug, also of Switzerland, won his third straight men‚Äôs race in an unofficial time of 1:25:28. It‚Äôs his sixth overall New York victory, a new record, surpassing the five wins of Kurt Fearnley.

Read more of our New York City Marathon coverage at the link in our bio. Photos by Uli Seit for The New York Times.

How U.S. Troops Were Harmed By Firing Their Own Guns

A secret U.S. offensive in 2016 and 2017 used an unusual strategy to fight the Islamic State. The plan: Put a minimal number of American troops on the ground and have them pound the enemy with relentless artillery fire. What no one foresaw was the devastating toll it would take on the troops who did the firing.

Research has started to reveal that as with hits in football, repeated blast exposure from firing heavy weapons may cause irreparable injury to the brain. It is a sprawling problem that the military is just starting to come to grips with.

Dave Philipps of The New York Times spoke to dozens of veterans experiencing mysterious, life-shattering mental and physical problems and investigated a type of brain injury that may have caused the problems.

Video by Dave Philipps, @boatcloak, Rebecca Suner, Ruru Kuo

Severe obesity is the fastest-rising subcategory among youth ‚Äî ‚Äúan epidemic within an epidemic,‚Äù as the American Academy of Pediatrics calls it.

Pictured here is 16-year-old Alexandra Duerte, who has been living with polycystic ovary syndrome and prediabetes since she was 10. Her doctor suggested bariatric surgery, an operation on the gastrointestinal tract that helps patients lose weight. Alexandra is one of the roughly 20% of children in the U.S. are living with obesity. Some can develop what were once considered adult illnesses: hypertension, diabetes, fatty liver disease. Obesity can also magnify mental-health problems.

How far should doctors go to treat obesity? Read the story at the link in our bio. Photograph by @kholoodeid.

More than 500 runners with disabilities and guides are participating in this year's New York City Marathon. Francesco Magisano is one of them: Sunday will mark the sixth time the 28-year-old, who lost his vision as a teenager, will run the race. 

But long before marathon day, Magisano started breaking in the new guide who will accompany him on the course: Nev Schulman, the producer and host of MTV‚Äôs "Catfish" reality TV show,  has run the marathon six times before, but never as a guide. The two men only recently started training together with Achilles, a group of runners with disabilities who met twice a week for runs in Central Park.They run be connected by a running tether that helps them navigate the course together. 

For Schulman, the inspiration to be a guide came during an encounter with an blind runner during a previous marathon. ‚ÄúI hear from behind: ‚ÄòBlind runner! Blind runner on your right!‚Äô and two guides guiding what I guess was a 50-something-year-old woman and they just really flew past me,‚Äù Schulman said.

Tap the link in our bio to read about how Magisano and Schulman are preparing for the race, where organizers expect 50,000 finishers on Sunday. Photos by @wattsanna_

On Oct. 7, Hamas terrorists staged a surprise attack on Israel, killing roughly 1,400 people in their homes, at a music festival and on the streets. 

For most, the threat dawned immediately. Israelis retreated to safe rooms, monitoring pleas for help they could not answer on WhatsApp, or worrying for hours with no news of loved ones. The events still haunt those who survived.

On Friday, President Biden met with the families of those killed or injured during the rampage last month that claimed the lives of 18 people at a bar and a bowling alley in Lewiston, Maine.

He also met with nurses, local officials and the law enforcement officers who spent two days in a manhunt for the killer. ‚ÄúJill and I are here on behalf of the American people to grieve with you, and make sure you know that you‚Äôre not alone,‚Äù Biden said after stopping by a makeshift memorial in Lewiston with his wife, Jill Biden. The president used the opportunity to urge Americans to seek consensus more broadly in the hopes of avoiding more of the spasms of deadly violence that have become a routine part of life in the U.S.

The Battle of the Bridge is the biggest football game of the year in Lewiston and Auburn, cities separated by a river in Maine. This season‚Äôs matchup came almost exactly a week after a gunman began a shooting spree that killed 18 people and wounded 13 others. 

The game, originally scheduled for last week but played on Wednesday, was a return to routine for the cities after the state‚Äôs deadliest mass shooting. It was a chance to celebrate in the open after days of sheltering in place during a terrifying manhunt.

‚ÄúLong after this game is over, no one is going to remember the score,‚Äù said Jason Versey, the Lewiston football coach. ‚ÄúPeople are going to remember that we came together.‚Äù

Tap the link in our bio to read more about the game and how the Lewiston community has come together following the tragedy. Photos by @acullenphoto

Ozempic, and drugs like it, have transformed how doctors treat diabetes and obesity. Now, some psychiatrists are turning to the drugs to counteract the weight gain that often comes with nearly all antipsychotics and some drugs used to treat depression and anxiety.

The New York Times heard from 13 leading mental health facilities and psychiatric departments at major health systems in the U.S. Their responses reflect a new debate in mental health care about whether to prescribe a drug patients will most likely take indefinitely, with only a limited understanding of how people with serious mental illness fare on these medications.

Of more than 3,000 counties in the U.S., Clallam County in Washington State is the only one that has voted for the winner of the presidential race every year since 1980. On a Saturday in October, in a small foundry, Erin Thompson watched as ‚Äúa man in heat-resistant attire pulled down his gold-plated visor, turned on his plasma torch and sliced into the face of Robert E. Lee.‚Äù The statue had stood in Charlottesville, Va., since 1924 ‚Äî and had been the subject of incredible controversy. A petition to remove the statue ‚Äî organized by Zyahna Bryant in 2016 ‚Äî led to a series of white nationalist rallies held to ensure it remained standing, which ultimately culminated in the death of counterprotester Heather D. Heyer. Now, a group called Swords Into Plowshares is repurposing the statues‚Äô bronze to make a new piece of public art. ‚ÄúThe way our communities dispose of these artifacts may influence America‚Äôs racial dynamic over the next century, just as erecting them did for the hundred-year period now ending,‚Äù @artcrimeprofessor writes. ‚Äú99 years after the monument‚Äôs installation and 158 years after the end of the Civil War, it‚Äôs high time we start figuring this out.‚Äù Click the link in our bio to read more.| üì∑ @ezeamosphotography and @audramelton #nytopinion

For the second year in a row, the number of illegal crossings at the U.S.-Mexico border surpassed two million, according to government data released this month.

The 2022 fiscal year set a record of 2.2 million illegal border crossings. These numbers do not include crossings at official checkpoints. Including those, migrant crossings in the 2023 fiscal year hit a record high.

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt really start out to do anything not the biggest possible,‚Äù Kim Kardashian said in a new interview with The New York Times. She was, specifically, talking about her shapewear brand, Skims, and how big she wanted it to be.

On Thursday she announced yet another Skims collaboration: a partnership with Swarovski, the Austrian crystal company known for its kitschy animals and rock star customizations. Founded four years ago, Skims went from being valued at $1.6 billion in 2021 to $4 billion last summer. Bobby Knight, one of college basketball‚Äôs signature coaches and a singular personality renowned for his tempestuousness and hubris, died on Wednesday at his home in Bloomington, Indiana. He was 83.

His death was announced in a statement on his website. It did not give a cause.

Mercurial and volatile, Knight was among the most polarizing characters in American sports. He was a brilliant coach who sought out intelligent players, deployed a ferocious man-to-man defense, extolled the virtues of precision passing and preached the necessities of never-ending hustle. Known as a principled perfectionist and a master teacher, he was also a driven competitor for whom losing was agony and a relentless motivator whose chief tool, it often seemed, was the anger-fueled rant.

Tap the link in our bio to read more about Knight, who found fame, glory and notoriety at Indiana University, where he was head coach for 29 years. Photo by Barton Silverman/The New York Times

In recent weeks, the Pakistani government abruptly declared that all foreign citizens living in the country without documents must leave by Nov. 1. 

The 1.7 million Afghans living illegally in Pakistan have come under mounting pressure, according to human rights groups and migrants. So far, more than 70,000 Afghans have left. Landlords have evicted Afghan tenants, fearing large fines if they don‚Äôt. Employers have fired undocumented Afghan workers. The police have raided neighborhoods popular among Afghans, arresting those without paperwork.

Rights groups have condemned Pakistan‚Äôs actions, worried about the possibility that some Afghans could face persecution in Afghanistan for past ties to Taliban opponents. Meanwhile, Pakistani officials have established several deportation centers nationwide. Many Afghans have faced devastating decisions about whether to try to stay in a country where they are no longer welcome or return to one where they have not lived for decades.

Nearly three years into an experiment that proponents hoped would spark a nationwide relaxation of drug laws, many in Oregon have turned against the decriminalization initiative known as Measure 110, which passed with 58% support in 2020. ‚Å†
‚Å†
People sprawled on sidewalks and using fentanyl with no fear of consequence have become a common sight in cities such as Eugene and Portland. Business owners and local leaders are upset, but so are liberal voters who hoped decriminalization would lead to more people getting help. In reality, few drug users are taking advantage of new state-funded rehabilitation programs.‚Å†
‚Å†
Change appears likely. A coalition of city officials, police chiefs and district attorneys recently called on the state legislature to recriminalize hard drugs. A measure to do so is in the works for next year‚Äôs ballot. A recent poll found the majority of Oregonians support the idea.‚Å†
‚Å†
The fundamental problem, according to law-enforcement officers and researchers, is that the threat of jail time hasn‚Äôt been replaced with a new incentive for people struggling with addiction to seek treatment.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some 6,000 tickets have been issued for drug possession since decriminalization went into effect in 2021, but just 92 people have called and completed assessments needed to connect them to services, according to the nonprofit that operates the helpline. The only penalty for those who don‚Äôt call is a $100 fine, which is rarely enforced.‚Å†
‚Å†
Advocates of drug decriminalization blame Oregon‚Äôs continued problems on nationwide trends, including the rise of deadly fentanyl and increased homelessness.‚Å†
‚Å†
They say Measure 110 is already succeeding at one of its goals: keeping people out of the criminal-justice system for drug possession. About 4,000 people were arrested for drug offenses in Oregon in 2022, down from 11,000 in 2020.‚Å†

The white-collar labor market is softening to a point that companies are encountering an issue that would have been unthinkable in the era known as the Great Resignation. ‚Å†
‚Å†
These days, too few people are voluntarily leaving their jobs.‚Å†
‚Å†
Turnover has declined so steeply at some large employers that companies now find themselves over budget on certain teams, requiring leaders to weigh whether to postpone projects or to cut additional staff as the end of year approaches. Other bosses worry about how to keep star employees engaged when there are far fewer vacant positions internally, making it harder to move people into new roles.‚Å†
‚Å†
The decline in quitting would seem a welcome development for bosses who spent years bemoaning high levels of job-hopping and rapidly rising salaries. But some executives said they have been caught by surprise at how quickly the labor-market dynamics flipped, posing new challenges.‚Å†
‚Å†
Morgan Stanley had layoffs in recent months in part because of low attrition within the 80,000-person Wall Street firm, CEO James Gorman said on a call with investors in mid-October.‚Å†
‚Å†
Employers try to accurately predict how many staffers will quit in a given year to help set budgets for teams and establish hiring plans. Software company ServiceNow uses a machine-learning model to anticipate the number of employees it expects will step down each quarter. Voluntary turnover this year has fallen below levels forecast by those models, said Sarah Tilley, senior vice president of global talent. She didn‚Äôt cite specific figures, but attrition among top-performing employees in 2023 is less than half of what it was in 2022.‚Å†

Astrophysicist Jason Steffen has spent his career trying to crack the deepest mysteries of the universe while studying exoplanets orbiting distant stars, dark matter and gravitation. In his spare time, he also tackles another impenetrable riddle of the galaxy: What is the best way to board airplanes?‚Å†
‚Å†
Steffen‚Äôs frustration with the boarding process began with an unpleasant trip to the airport in Seattle, where he waited in many lines. He thought the last one, at the jet bridge, was unnecessary.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThere should be a solution to this‚Äîno matter how weird it might be,‚Äù the 48-year-old said.‚Å†
‚Å†
His annoyance, which you don‚Äôt have to be an astrophysicist to understand, led him to develop what he says is the optimal boarding strategy.‚Å†
‚Å†
Here‚Äôs how it works: The first person to board a single-aisle jet like a Boeing 737 is the passenger in the window seat of the last row. Say that‚Äôs 30A. The next person would be exactly two rows away in 28A, followed by 26A, 24A and 22A until the window seats in even rows on the right side were full. Next are the window seats in even rows on the left side: 30F, 28F, 26F and so on. Then come window seats in odd rows on the right and left starting from the back. The same patterns apply to middle seats and aisle seats until the last person on board plops into the front row.‚Å†
‚Å†
The idea is to reduce the probability of traffic jams. If the primary bottleneck of the boarding process is people waiting in the aisle, mostly because of how long it takes for others to load their luggage, Steffen‚Äôs fix maximizes the number of passengers stuffing their bags into overhead bins simultaneously. It takes a serial process (one at a time) and makes it parallel (several at a time).‚Å†
‚Å†
Steffen‚Äôs academic theories might be too idealistic to overcome the realities of the business, but it‚Äôs still worth exploring why they work.‚Å†
‚Å†

While anxiety, depression and other mental-health conditions started to climb among children before Covid, they soared during the isolation and disruption of the pandemic. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The increased demand for treatment exacerbated a shortage of available mental-health services. This has left desperate families pouring into emergency departments that legally can turn no one away. ‚Å†

‚Å†
Teague eventually found residential facilities, but it took weeks to get her in. After being discharged from one facility, Iris tried to kill herself. After a mental-health evaluation, Iris, who had just turned 18, was transferred to an adult psychiatric unit at an Albuquerque hospital, where she was discharged after five days with a treatment plan that would have required her to wait months for a psychiatrist.‚Å†

Teague used her medical connections to cobble together a treatment plan, which includes a local therapist and a dietitian from Colorado who helps her daughter remotely. ‚Å†

Online shoppers‚Äîto add to the specters of shipping delays and front porch-theft‚Äîhave a new annoyance: accidentally ordering doll-size versions of things.‚Å†
‚Å†
Emma Platt, 41, a U.K.-based graphic designer, bought a set of coat hangers labeled as ‚Äúsmall‚Äù from the Chinese fashion site Shein for her part-time business selling secondhand children‚Äôs clothes.‚Å†

‚ÄúI probably couldn‚Äôt fit anything but Barbie clothes on there,‚Äù Platt said of the mini hangers that arrived. ‚Å†
‚Å†
It turns out it‚Äôs not uncommon. Online marketplaces sell tiny pink cowboy hats. They also sell miniature pencil sharpeners, palm-size kitchen utensils, scaled-down books and itsy-bitsy camping chairs. Many of the minuscule objects aren‚Äôt clearly advertised.‚Å†
‚Å†
Shoppers have gotten lazy when clicking ‚Äúbuy‚Äù and assume‚Äîoften wrongly‚Äîwhat size they‚Äôre getting, said Brendan Witcher, a principal analyst at research and advisory firm Forrester. But there is no doubt some online sellers deliberately trick customers into buying smaller and often cheaper-to-produce items, he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
Common tactics include displaying products against a white background rather than in room sets or on models, or photographing items with a perspective that makes them appear bigger than they really are. Dimensions can be hidden deep in the product description, or not included at all.‚Å†
‚Å†
In those instances, the duped consumer ‚Äúmay say, well, it‚Äôs only $1, $2, maybe $3‚Äîwhat‚Äôs the harm?‚Äù Witcher said. When the item arrives the shopper may be confused, amused or frustrated, but unlikely to complain or demand a refund.‚Å†

As the cost of having fun goes up, so do the odds that you‚Äôll feel let down.‚Å†
‚Å†
The cost of admissions and fees for entertainment rose faster than the cost of many staple goods last year, according to data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics. That has helped raise standards for the amount of fun we expect for our money‚Äîand triggered quick disappointment when our experiences don‚Äôt live up to the price. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Someone who scores cheap flights to Europe may give the trip five stars before the plane even boards. Someone who spends half their paycheck on playoff tickets may get cranky about it by halftime. ‚Å†
‚Å†
And people are spending for now. Corie Barry, Best Buy‚Äôs CEO, said at a conference last month that ‚Äúexperiences are really where people are willing to pay‚Äù and that this was dragging on demand for expensive electronics. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Studies on money and happiness tell us that paying for experiences tends to bring us greater pleasures than buying stuff, because those experiences can deliver payoffs before, during and after they happen. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Dissatisfaction is more likely when money is tighter, a 2022 study in the Journal of Consumer Research found. People feel worse about purchases of both things and experiences and write more negative reviews, researchers found. This regret often stems from thinking about all the other ways the money could have been used instead.‚Å†

The armies of people who make clothes for Western brands‚Äîsome of the lowest-paid factory workers in the world‚Äîare protesting for better wages, a sign that the era of ultracheap labor, and ultracheap clothes, on which many companies rely is increasingly under strain.‚Å†
‚Å†
Garment workers in Bangladesh make as little as $3 a day, or about $75 a month. In recent days, tens of thousands have refused to work, calling for the minimum wage to be raised to nearly three times that amount. Demonstrations have spiraled, with factories set ablaze and machines smashed. Some three hundred factories stopped operations.‚Å†
‚Å†
Sewing operator Hamim Shikder, who joined protests, said the roughly $125 a month he earns‚Äîafter 50 hours of overtime‚Äîis spent on his son‚Äôs school fees, increasingly expensive groceries and other essentials. When his wife recently got sick with dengue he had to borrow money for medical bills. ‚ÄúWhatever amount I get, I have to spend,‚Äù he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
The core of the protests, that workers need higher wages to make even a basic living, has drawn widespread support, including from fashion giants H&M, Gap and Zara-parent Inditex, which source from the country. But no one can agree on who should foot the bill.‚Å†
‚Å†
Factory owners in Bangladesh say that for them to hike wages in a big way, Western brands that are their top buyers need to pay more for clothes. Although the big names in fashion publicly support higher pay, in practice they balk when costs go up and threaten to shift their orders to other countries, said Faruque Hassan, president of the Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association.‚Å†
‚Å†
Western brands say they support a boost in Bangladesh‚Äôs minimum wage, but most haven‚Äôt said by how much. Workers sewing clothes for them often make substantially more than the minimum wage but far less than what unions are demanding and what international organizations that benchmark living-wage standards consider to be enough.‚Å†

The U.S. has a lot of problems that desperately need solving. These aren‚Äôt Republican or Democratic challenges. They are American challenges. They affect every one of us, and we need to face them together, writes @joemanchin for @wsjopinion.

There are enough votes in Congress to solve or at least make headway against every one of these problems. A genuine commitment to legislating would put America on firmer footing for the next 20 years. But the Democratic and Republican machines have no interest in solutions. Instead, they stoke outrage because doing so brings them fame and funding.

Today, the business of politics is about monetizing anger and getting paid for it. And business has never been better. Not for me.

I have made one of the toughest decisions of my life and decided that I won‚Äôt run for re-election to the Senate. I am proud of having worked every day of the past 42 years trying to make things better in the Mountain State. But this moment in the nation‚Äôs history is so filled with peril and political dysfunction that I want to work not only for my beloved West Virginia but for all Americans. Working together, I want to eliminate what is standing in the way of so many obvious and popular solutions.

While the Democratic and Republican parties increasingly cater to the extremes, most Americans are moderate, levelheaded folks, and they are plain worn out. We need to reaffirm that country should always come before party.

Hundreds of thousands of migrants from all over the world are making their way to the Southwest U.S. border, with American and Mexican authorities reporting a surge in apprehensions of people from Asia and Africa as human smuggling networks widen their reach across the globe.‚Å†
‚Å†
Arrests at the Southwest U.S. border of migrants from China, India and other distant countries, including Mauritania and Senegal, tripled to 214,000 during the fiscal year that ended in September from 70,000 in the previous fiscal year, according to U.S. Customs and Border Protection data. Fewer than 19,000 migrants from Asia and Africa were apprehended in the fiscal year ended September 2021.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThese days, we are dealing with 120 nationalities and 60 different languages,‚Äù said Enrique Lucero, head of the migrant support unit of the Tijuana city government, across from San Diego.‚Å†
‚Å†
Travelers say they exchange information and share videos of U.S.-bound routes on Tik Tok and Facebook, while smugglers offer lodging and travel agencies advertise transport services. Most Asian and African migrants make multiple airport stopovers in what are coming to be known as ‚Äúdonkey flights‚Äù to reach countries such as Brazil, Ecuador or Nicaragua, which have few or no visa requirements for some nationalities. Once they set foot in Latin America, they move north in buses or cars and stay at hotels booked by smuggling organizations.‚Å†
‚Å†
For the second year in a row, arrests by the Border Patrol at the U.S. Southern border surpassed two million. Most of them, almost nine out of 10 apprehensions, are of migrants from Latin America and the Caribbean. But the surge in so-called extracontinental migrants poses a challenge for the U.S. because deporting migrants to Africa and Asia is time-consuming, expensive and sometimes not possible.‚Å†

Those who remained and their descendants‚Äîcolloquially called ‚Äô48 Arabs‚Äîmake up about 20% of the population and are dubbed Arab-Israelis by the state. They have largely sought integration in Israel and enjoy equal rights on paper, but many say they feel like second-class citizens.‚Å†

‚ÄúWhenever there is a war or anything, it comes back against us as ‚Äô48 Arabs,‚Äù said Darawshe‚Äôs sister.‚Å†

The backlash demonstrates the fragile standing of Israel‚Äôs sizable Arab population‚Äîa group that says it is being found guilty by association, even while counting its members among victims of Hamas‚Äôs horrifying attack. ‚Å†

On the wall of the border crossing between bombed-out Gaza and Egypt‚Äôs Sinai desert there is a list. The names on it have been a source of hope, despair and confusion for the hundreds of foreign families wanting to escape the Palestinian enclave under Israeli fire.‚Å†
‚Å†
American sisters Jana and Mena Timraz rejoiced when their names appeared on the list on Thursday. But their parents, brothers and Jana‚Äôs husband, who aren‚Äôt U.S. citizens, were missing from the roster. ‚ÄúMy husband said ‚ÄòGo save yourself and son‚Äîthat‚Äôs the most important thing,‚Äô‚Äù recalls Jana, cradling her 3-month-old son in a hotel in Cairo, having left the rest of her family behind in Gaza.‚Å†
‚Å†
Their story is among the tales of heart-rending dilemmas and bureaucratic hurdles emerging from those fleeing Gaza in the past few days. After a weekslong diplomatic wrangle to get the frontier open for foreign nationals and the injured, the task of choosing who goes through is arguably more arduous.‚Å†
‚Å†
The exodus was complicated further by the suspension of crossings on Saturday morning, when Hamas, the U.S.-designated terror organization that runs the Gaza Strip, said it wouldn‚Äôt open the border unless Israel agreed to the safe passage of ambulances heading to the crossing. An ambulance near the largest hospital in Gaza City was struck Friday by the Israelis, who said they were targeting Hamas militants using the vehicle. The border opened again on Monday.‚Å†
‚Å†
About 60 different nations have asked Egypt for around 7,600 foreign nationals‚Äîmany of Palestinian heritage‚Äîto be allowed to leave Gaza, according to senior Egyptian officials. Among them are between 500 and 600 Americans. In its first three days of operation, some 1,027 dual nationals went through the crossing. On Saturday, though, departures dried up altogether, before being restored on Monday, when 329 civilians went through. The Hamas-run Palestinian border authority didn‚Äôt respond to requests for comment.‚Å†

When movements such as #MeToo or Black Lives Matter came into the national spotlight, companies took broad stands against sexism or racism, issuing forceful statements and organizing candid conversations. The muted discussion around the Israel-Hamas conflict is a sharp turn. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Employees are criticizing their companies‚Äô responses as tepid or tardy, and saying they feel as though leaders want to avoid the subject.‚Å†
‚Å†
Jewish employees such as Alyssa Bleser, chief legal officer at a cannabis company, say they‚Äôre troubled by rising antisemitism and feeling alienated and unsupported by the lack of response from co-workers and bosses. ‚ÄúI would like to see my non-Jewish colleagues and friends speak up,‚Äù says Bleser.‚Å†
‚Å†
After her 11-year-old daughter was told by a classmate that she and other Jews should die, Bleser emailed her CEO a statement she‚Äôd written in support of Israel, suggesting he circulate it among investors. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The CEO, Jonathan Morrison, didn‚Äôt circulate the statement but later invited Bleser and her husband to discuss the conflict. He says he prefers to show support to his Jewish colleagues one-on-one, adding that it feels more meaningful that way.‚Å†
‚Å†
Many company leaders are taking a similar route, given the fraught, complex history between Israel and the Palestinians and the sense that there is no right thing to say. ‚ÄúCEOs, they‚Äôre like, nuh-uh, not getting dragged into this one,‚Äù says Johnny C. Taylor Jr., head of the human-resources professional association SHRM.‚Å†
‚Å†
Speaking out at work, or outside it, can exact a professional toll, workers say. Some people who‚Äôve shared views publicly have lost jobs. Workers from California to Chicago say in interviews that they believed they‚Äôve been reported to their employers for voicing pro-Palestinian sentiment online. ‚Å†

When girls at Westfield High School in New Jersey found out boys were sharing nude photos of them in group chats, they were shocked, and not only because it was an invasion of privacy. The images weren‚Äôt real.‚Å†
‚Å†
Students said one or more classmates used an online tool powered by artificial intelligence to make the images, then shared them with others. The discovery has sparked uproar in Westfield, an affluent town outside New York City.‚Å†
‚Å†
Digitally altered or faked images and videos have exploded along with the availability of free or cheap AI tools. While celebrity likenesses from Oprah Winfrey to Pope Francis have drawn media attention, the overwhelming majority of faked images are pornographic, experts say.‚Å†
‚Å†
The lack of clarity on such images‚Äô legality‚Äîand how or whether to punish their makers‚Äîhas parents, schools and law enforcement running to catch up as AI speeds ahead.‚Å†
‚Å†
Some Westfield parents said their daughters have felt humiliated and powerless, and worry about damage to the girls should the images surface later. And they are upset that no resolution is forthcoming.‚Å†
‚Å†
Even among parents, there is no consensus. Some called for harsh punishment for whoever created the images. Others deemed it a youthful transgression that should be forgiven.‚Å†
‚Å†
The debate and its aftermath are likely to continue for months. Westfield police are investigating, and a state senator has asked county prosecutors to look into the case.‚Å†

Ittai Gradel, an academic‚Äìturned‚Äìgem dealer in Denmark, was trawling eBay a decade ago when he thought he had stumbled across a gold mine.‚Å†
‚Å†
Gradel saw a seller advertising a glass gem from the 19th century. Gradel immediately recognized it as something much more valuable: an agate Roman Medusa cameo from the second century. He snapped it up for ¬£15 plus postage, then turned around and sold it to a collector for a couple of thousand pounds.‚Å†
‚Å†
In the following years, the same seller kept unearthing incredible finds at rock-bottom prices. Gradel inquired as to how he had come across these items. The seller said he had acquired them from his grandfather, who died in 1953. The oddly credible backstory left Gradel comfortable that he had encountered every dealer‚Äôs dream seller. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Then, in 2016, the seller posted a piece on eBay by mistake. Intrigued by the item, Gradel screenshotted it. But the seller quickly removed it from the website and said that it actually belonged to his sister, who didn‚Äôt want to sell it. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Gradel thought not much more about it. But in 2020, he came across an image on the British Museum‚Äôs website that showed the exact same item in its collection. Furthermore, the color photograph was recent. It suddenly dawned on Gradel: There was a thief in the British Museum. ‚ÄúAnd he was likely still within the walls,‚Äù he says.‚Å†
‚Å†
So began an antiques whodunit that has shaken the premise behind the museum‚Äôs most important reason for existing: that it is the best place to safely house some of the world‚Äôs greatest treasures. ‚Å†

Most funny people will say that where there‚Äôs laughter, there‚Äôs usually pain. Julia Louis-Dreyfus knows the reverse is also true.‚Å†
‚Å†
Even while she explores new emotional depths in her work, she can‚Äôt help but find the funny. The comedy icon is bringing her singular point of view to more serious projects involving questions of marital strife, family tragedy and the wisdom of older women. The turn reflects, in part, where she is in her life right now.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI have a lot of experience and I can bring it to bear,‚Äù @officialjld tells @wsjmag. ‚ÄúAnd I‚Äôm really interested in trying new things.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs been five years since Louis-Dreyfus finished treatment for stage-two breast cancer. She used to feel immortal, she says, but not anymore. With the relief of remission comes a determination to make her next years count.‚Å†
‚Å†
Louis-Dreyfus‚Äôs latest project is ‚ÄúWiser Than Me,‚Äù her first podcast and her most personally revealing work yet. At 62, she is still in her second act but eager to learn about the third, bringing on guests such as designer Diane von Furstenberg, 76, singer Darlene Love, 82, and comedy icon Carol Burnett, 90.‚Å†
‚Å†
The old ladies are talking, she‚Äôs listening, and the show‚Äôs a hit.‚Å†

In the fall of 2021, a consultant named Arturo Bejar sent Meta Platforms Chief Executive Mark Zuckerberg an unusual note.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI wanted to bring to your attention what l believe is a critical gap in how we as a company approach harm, and how the people we serve experience it,‚Äù he began. Though Meta regularly issued public reports suggesting that it was largely on top of safety issues on its platforms, he wrote, the company was deluding itself.‚Å†
‚Å†
The experience of young users on Meta‚Äôs Instagram‚Äîwhere Bejar had spent the previous two years working as a consultant‚Äîwas especially acute. In a subsequent email to Instagram head Adam Mosseri, one statistic stood out: One in eight users under the age of 16 said they had experienced unwanted sexual advances on the platform over the previous seven days.‚Å†
‚Å†
For Bejar, that finding was hardly a surprise. His daughter and her friends had been receiving unsolicited penis pictures and other forms of harassment on the platform since the age of 14, he wrote, and Meta‚Äôs systems generally ignored their reports‚Äîor responded by saying that the harassment didn‚Äôt violate platform rules.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI asked her why boys keep doing that,‚Äù Bejar wrote to Zuckerberg and his top lieutenants. ‚ÄúShe said if the only thing that happens is they get blocked, why wouldn‚Äôt they?‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
For the well-being of its users, Bejar argued, Meta needed to change course, focusing less on a flawed system of rules-based policing and more on addressing such bad experiences. ‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI am appealing to you because I believe that working this way will require a culture shift,‚Äù Bejar wrote to Zuckerberg‚Äîthe company would have to acknowledge that its existing approach to governing Facebook and Instagram wasn‚Äôt working.‚Å†
‚Å†
Two years later, the problems Bejar identified remain unresolved, and new blind spots have emerged. The company launched a sizable child-safety task force in June, following revelations that Instagram was cultivating connections among large-scale networks of pedophilic users, an issue the company says it‚Äôs working to address.‚Å†

Pozzuoli, a seaside town about 8 miles west of Naples, has had more than 2,500 earthquake tremors in the past three months. So far, few have been large, but residents are on edge: They live on top of a supervolcano, a classification given to about 20 of the world‚Äôs largest volcanoes. The constant earthquakes are a sign of volcanic activity deep underground.‚Å†
‚Å†
Vesuvius, southeast of Naples, which destroyed Pompeii in the first century A.D., is the region‚Äôs most famous volcano. But modern volcanologists are far more worried about the cluster of low-lying craters around Pozzuoli known as Campi Flegrei. The 80-square-mile depression is home to more than a dozen conical volcanoes, several crater lakes‚Äîand half a million residents. Another 800,000 people live just outside the depression.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs nonstop earthquakes here,‚Äù said Luca Averna, a part-time fisherman, during a recent 3.6-magnitude tremor. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre used to it, but that doesn‚Äôt mean we aren‚Äôt afraid.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
In Campi Flegrei, like in Yellowstone and the world‚Äôs other supervolcanoes, the probability of a catastrophic eruption is low but not nil, said Alessandro Iannace, a geology professor at the University of Naples Federico II who wrote a popular geology book.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúThe difference is that in Yellowstone, if you think the eruption is coming, you can send the tourists home and close the park for four years,‚Äù said Iannace. ‚ÄúYou can‚Äôt do that with Campi Flegrei. There are just too many people there.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
An eruption in Campi Flegrei isn‚Äôt imminent, but earthquakes have weakened the volcano, making a rupture in the crust more likely, according to a recent study by researchers at Italy‚Äôs national institute and University College London.‚Å†
‚Å†

FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was convicted of stealing billions of dollars from customers of the doomed crypto exchange, in what prosecutors called one of the biggest financial frauds in U.S. history.‚Å†
‚Å†
The verdict, delivered by a New York federal jury, capped the stunning fall of the onetime crypto king, whose shaggy-haired boy-genius persona helped catapult FTX into a powerhouse trading platform that sponsored sports teams and ran glitzy ads featuring football great Tom Brady, model Gisele B√ºndchen and comedian Larry David.

The crypto exchange abruptly crashed a year ago, with customers losing billions of dollars. Bankman-Fried, 31, was indicted in December 2022 and agreed to leave his home in the Bahamas to face an array of fraud charges. SZA has become one of the most successful artists of her generation with her brash, anxious overshares.‚Å†
‚Å†
The 34-year-old, born Sol√°na Rowe, has been churning out intimate, thorny, genre-blending hits about self-love and self-loathing since she signed to the rap label Top Dawg Entertainment in 2013.‚Å†
‚Å†
Her debut album, ‚ÄúCtrl,‚Äù hasn‚Äôt left the Billboard 200 chart since July 2017. Her follow-up, ‚ÄúSOS,‚Äù dropped in December 2022; its 10 weeks on the chart made it the longest-running No. 1 album by a female artist of the decade. It also broke a record for most weeks atop the R&B chart.‚Å†
‚Å†
The five years between ‚ÄúCtrl‚Äù and ‚ÄúSOS‚Äù elevated @sza to superstar status. She became more famous by being less present. Her fans are ravenous, rushing to stream her music and selling out dates on her first headline arena tour.‚Å†
‚Å†
Meanwhile, she‚Äôs obsessive about the music, and she takes every song personally. ‚ÄúI‚Äôll die about that s‚Äît every time,‚Äù she says. Everyone wants more songs, faster, now. SZA insists on taking her time.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúWhen I leave the studio, I feel better and empty,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no better sleep than empty-brain sleep, and that can only come after I‚Äôve been in the studio for 10 hours and done something good in there.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
Though her circuitous problems‚Äîlove, heartbreak, ghosting, getting ghosted‚Äîhave become signature subjects, she says she wants to write about the good stuff, too. ‚ÄúI go through so many other moments in life that are amazing, things that I could never describe,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI haven‚Äôt even tried to find words for those things.‚Äù‚Å†

The new hot section on the plane isn‚Äôt at the very front.‚Å†
‚Å†
Not quite business class and definitely not coach, premium-economy cabins are hooking travelers willing to treat themselves to extra comfort for about double the price of a coach seat on some flights.‚Å†
‚Å†
With offerings labeled Premium Plus, Premium Select or Premium Economy, airlines are expanding these sections, which typically come with roomy seats, early boarding, free alcohol and better meals. Airlines say they appeal to travelers with more disposable income, especially on long-haul flights where business-class seats can run thousands of dollars more.‚Å†
‚Å†
‚ÄúI refer to it as an upper-middle cabin for the upper-middle class,‚Äù says Jay Sorensen, an industry consultant and president of IdeaWorksCompany. These sections appeal to travelers on work trips with budget-conscious employers, and vacationers who want some comforts without shelling out for business class.‚Å†
‚Å†
For flights to Europe from the U.S., round-trip tickets in the premium-economy cabin average about double the cost of main-cabin tickets, according to a fare analysis conducted by IdeaWorksCompany. Business-class seats on those routes are roughly double the cost of premium-economy seats, the analysis found.‚Å†
‚Å†
Travelers who do the math on upgrades say the decision depends on the costs, which can vary depending on demand and time of purchase. Customers also factor in flight length, whom they are traveling with and how much legroom they need. ‚Å†

The rate of babies dying in America increased significantly for the first time in two decades, raising new alarms about maternal-infant health in the U.S.‚Å†
‚Å†
The nation‚Äôs infant-mortality rate rose 3% from 2021 to 2022, reversing a decadeslong overall decline, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said Wednesday. The rate increased from 5.44 infant deaths for every 1,000 births to 5.6 in 2022, a statistically significant uptick.‚Å†
‚Å†
The U.S. rate is double that of many developed countries. Globally, baby death rates have fallen for decades, though five countries that have reported their rates this year recorded increases for last year.‚Å†
‚Å†
The death rate for women who give birth has also been rising in the U.S. Researchers who study the issues said the pair of trends indicate more women giving birth are facing challenges getting proper care.‚Å†
‚Å†
The health of the mother is closely linked to the risks to tiny infants. Complications during pregnancy was one of the fastest-rising causes of infant death, the CDC said, along with dangerous bacterial infections called sepsis.‚Å†
‚Å†

In a factory in Israel not far from the Gaza border, Jews and Arabs have for years worked side by side making SodaStream seltzer machines for homes around the world. ‚Å†
‚Å†
Together, the colleagues feasted at Ramadan and lighted candles for Hanukkah. They visited one another‚Äôs homes and attended the weddings and funerals of their co-workers‚Äô family members. Throughout past conflicts in the region, they have called their workplace an ‚Äúisland of peace.‚Äù ‚Å†
‚Å†
That harmony is now being tested.‚Å†
‚Å†
SodaStream‚Äôs presence in the region has put it in the middle of controversy over the years. A prior SodaStream factory, located in the West Bank, sparked calls for a boycott of the brand.‚Å†
‚Å†
The current factory is in the Negev Desert in southern Israel. The Gaza border is about 20 miles away. Before the Hamas terrorist attacks on Oct. 7, the SodaStream facility had about 1,500 employees, roughly a third of them Bedouin. More than 100 were Palestinians bused in every day from the West Bank. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The factory is now operating with about two-thirds of its usual staff, the company said. At least one SodaStream employee has been killed, and one has been taken hostage. Other staffers have lost close family members.‚Å†
‚Å†
SodaStream was founded more than a century ago in the U.K. and later moved to Israel. PepsiCo bought the business in 2018. SodaStream has weathered past Israeli-Palestinian conflicts, but this crisis is different from any the company has faced before.‚Å†

It said the policy breaches human rights laws by potentially leaving the people sent there open to that risk.
 
UK PM Rishi Sunak said it was "not the outcome we wanted" and the government would "now consider next steps".

"We cannot change the past; however, this decision provides the Army and the American people an opportunity to learn from this difficult moment in our history."
 
The US Army has overturned convictions of 110 black soldiers who were arrested after the 1917 Houston Riots.
 
A military review found the soldiers were not given fair trials and were "wrongly treated" because of their race.
 
The riots took place after months of racial provocations against members of a regiment known as "Buffalo Soldiers".
 
Amid rumours of additional threats from a white mob, a group of armed black soldiers assembled in the Texas city, where clashes erupted.
 
The army convicted 110 soldiers from the regiment and ultimately nineteen were executed, while others were sentenced to life behind bars.
 
It remains the largest mass execution of American soldiers by the US Army.
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews‚Äôs bio to find out what will be done to characterise the soldiers‚Äô military service as honourable.

Many telescopes have captured images of space, like The Horsehead gas cloud where stars are being born, but none with the width and sharpness that Euclid can.
 
Euclid will now survey a third of the sky over the next six years to gather clues about so-called dark matter and dark energy.
 
"We don't currently understand 95% of the Universe, a universe that is 13.8 billion years old."
 
Tap the link in @BBCNews's bio to read how Euclid was developed and how it will gather the data.

And you can keep in touch with all your News on the updated BBC News app.  All the top stories, breaking news, live reporting, and the option to follow news topics that match your interests.

Comedian John Oliver has succeeded in his campaign to have what he describes as a weird, puking bird with a colorful mullet win New Zealand‚Äôs Bird of the Century contest.

Arson likely caused a massive weekend fire that has indefinitely closed a vital section of a freeway in Los Angeles, California Gov. Gavin Newsom said Monday.

He did not say whether there were any suspects or persons of interest. The fire left the columns of Interstate 10 charred and chipped and the deck guardrails were twisted and blackened. Crews shored up the most damaged section for the safety of workers clearing the debris. It‚Äôs still unclear what structural damage, if any, the blaze caused to the freeway.

Engineers were assessing the situation Monday.

The freeway is used by 300,000 vehicles daily and the closure is expected to be felt well beyond the city, including possibly slowing the transport of goods from the twin ports of LA and Long Beach, federal officials have said. The ports are among the nation‚Äôs largest and handle more than half the goods coming into the U.S. President Joe Biden had been briefed on the fire that erupted Saturday.

More than 180,000 people across France, including 100,000 in Paris, marched peacefully on Sunday to protest against rising antisemitism in the wake of Israel‚Äôs ongoing war against Hamas in Gaza.‚Å†
‚Å†
Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne, representatives of several parties on the left, conservatives and centrists of President Emmanuel Macron‚Äôs party as well as far-right leader Marine Le Pen attended Sunday‚Äôs march in the French capital amid tight security. Macron did not attend, but expressed his support for the protest and called on citizens to rise up against ‚Äúthe unbearable resurgence of unbridled antisemitism.‚Äù‚Å†
‚Å†
However, the leader of the far-left France Unbowed party, Jean-Luc Melenchon, stayed away from the march, saying last week on X, formerly Twitter, that the march would be a meeting of ‚Äúfriends of unconditional support for the massacre‚Äù in Gaza.‚Å†
‚Å†
The interior ministry said at least 182,000 people marched in several in French cities in response to the call launched by the leaders of the parliament‚Äôs upper and lower houses. No major incident has been reported, it said.‚Å†

Paris authorities deployed 3,000 police troops along the route of the protest called by the leaders of the Senate and parliament‚Äôs lower house, the National Assembly, amid an alarming increase in anti-Jewish acts in France since the start of Israel‚Äôs war against Hamas after its Oct. 7 surprise attack on Israel.‚Å†

The Supreme Court is adopting its first code of ethics, in the face of sustained criticism over undisclosed trips and gifts from wealthy benefactors to some justices.

The policy was issued by the court Monday. The justices, who have hinted at internal deliberations over an ethics code, last met Thursday in their private conference room at the court. The justices said in an unsigned statement that they have long adhered to ethics standards.

‚ÄúThe absence of a Code, however, has led in recent years to the misunderstanding that the Justices of this Court, unlike all other jurists in this country, regard themselves as unrestricted by any ethics rules,‚Äù the justices wrote. ‚ÄúTo dispel this misunderstanding, we are issuing this Code, which largely represents a codification of principles that we have long regarded as governing our conduct.‚Äù

The issue has vexed the court for several months, over a series of stories questioning the ethical practices of the justices. Many of those stories focused on Justice Clarence Thomas and his failure to disclose travel and other financial ties with wealthy conservative donors including Harlan Crow and the Koch brothers. But Justices Samuel Alito and Sonia Sotomayor also have been under scrutiny.

Three justices, Amy Coney Barrett, Elena Kagan and Brett Kavanaugh, have voiced support for an ethics code in recent months. In May, Chief Justice John Roberts said there was more the court could do to ‚Äúadhere to the highest ethical standards,‚Äù without providing any specifics.

In the face of human-caused climate change impacting water access and weather patterns in the Willamette Valley ‚Äî a region known for hops growing ‚Äî farmers are using all the new strategies they can get to stay afloat and provide for large and small breweries alike.‚Å†
‚Å†
Climate change is anticipated to only further the challenges producers are already seeing in two key beer crops, hops and barley. Some hops and barley growers in the U.S. say they‚Äôve already seen their crops impacted by extreme heat, drought and unpredictable growing seasons.‚Å†
‚Å†
Researchers have known for a while that beer production will be affected by climate change, said Mirek Trnka, a professor at the Global Change Research Institute. He and his team recently authored a study modeling the effect of climate change on hops, out last month in Nature Communications, that projected that yields in Europe will decrease between four to 18% by 2050. His first study on hops 15 years ago issued a similar warning to his latest paper.‚Å†
‚Å†
That‚Äôs why some are working on varieties of hops that can better withstand summer heat, warmer winters, changing pests and diseases and less snowfall, which could mean less available irrigation, said Shaun Townsend, an associate professor and senior researcher at Oregon State University. Townsend is working on a project where he subjects hops to drought stress to eventually create more drought-tolerant varieties.‚Å†
‚Å†
It‚Äôs no easy task, one that can take a decade, and one that also has to take into account brewers‚Äô main considerations, taste and yield. But the possibility of running out of water is a reality that‚Äôs on people‚Äôs radars, he said.‚Å†
‚Å†
